Oh. come on! On the moon you can use ... made out of tin foil? Sorry to say that. But: are you mad? Have you actually seen the structure beneath the "tin foil", which actually were many layers of mylar used as insulation and meteor shield at the same time? Yes, there is a structure beneath that insulation! There are lots of people out there, trying to actually educate audiences about the moon landings, about the hardware used, techniques, etc. Those people work hard to counter arguments like "how can the LM have worked, since it was built from tin foil and bicycle screws".

Also. The percentages in the beginning. Yes, we had a 100% success rate at Titan. If it had failed, the percentage would be 0%, because there was just one single attempt. To assign some percentage to that is mathematically not wrong, but is pretty meaningless. If the next attept fails, the number would be down to 50% and would be the lowest of them.

Actually, the US has had good success with their lander and rover Mars missions with seven successes out of eight attempts.  Two of the rovers are still in operation to this day.  The Russians have had relatively poor success in landing equipment on Mars.  Out of eight attempts, just one survived, only to transmit less than 15 seconds of data before going silent.
